text: Plum, mango, spruce, hops, and grapefruit aromas. The taste is guava, mango, grapefruit, orange rind, marijuana and stone fruits. Translucent reddish amber with a thin, light tan head. This is fruity as all hell and Im liking it. I also have the munchies.

A lightly hazed dark amber ale esb with a thin off white head. In aroma, nice biscuit malt with resinous floral hops, light orange pulp, light tropical fruits, very nice. In mouth, a nice biscuit malt with resinous orange hops, oily mouth feel, nice and smooth, surprisingly well done for the style. Bottle at Pushkinwows New squirter inauguration.

650ml bottle. Pours a slightly hazy orange-amber with a medium, frothy, long lasting, off-white head that leaves curtains of lace. Sweet fruity aroma of mango, pineapple, orange, peach and floral with caramel malt in the background. Sweet fruity flavour of mango, guava, orange peel, peach, apricot, light pine resin and caramel malt with a dry, hoppy, bitter finish. Light to medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Wow, delicious and refreshing. Awesome, a world class ESB.
22oz bottle pours a brown color with a bit of head. Delicious hop balance with the malt. The hop bitterness lingers without any harsh flavors.
Bottle shared. Surprisingly tasty stuff, lots of peach and apricot, decent malty backbone, pretty cool for an ESB, definitely one of the best Ive had.

Bottle shared. Thanks Tim! Pours a copper color with a finger of foam that lingers. Huge tropical fruit bouquet dominates the nose. Super juicy with a very new world nose. Good carbonation with cherry and citrus tang on the palate. Quite a bitter finish that lingers. Very nice.

Pours beautifully amber, nice foamy look. Aroma full of tropical fruits, some aromatic hops, fragrant. Tastes light, malt sweetness balanced with hops, easygoing and clean. Very modern interpretation of ESB. Lingering hop bitterness ensues.

Deep amber color. Lots of apricots, peaches and earthy notes. The hops are very bright for the style. Well balanced, very earthy, with good malt backbone. Modest bitter finish. Excellent new world example of the style. Well balanced.
On holiday in Canada 650ml bottle amber coloured body with a white head and a spicy yeast citrus hop aroma a spicy citrus fruity herby sweet dry bitter taste with a alcholic bitter finish

Thanks to Matt for this brew! Liquide ambré à moitié filtré présentant une mousse bien fournie aux allures fières et nobles. Vapeurs fort agréables de houblons du Nouveau Monde sur base maltée typiquement anglaise. Les houblons sont très intenses pour le style.Quantité importante de fruits tels le pamplemousse et le citron. Le malt sert dassis confortable et fiable à ce cocktail de fruits qui na cependant rien dune Pale Ale. Bonne quantité de malts caramels et de sucres céréaliers qui balancent à merveille la légèreté des houblons. Cocktail dune grande fraîcheur en bouche où les houblons apportent à la fois une importante amertume et un profil aromatique des plus agréables. Encore une belle présence de grains germés et entiers dans cette bière dune grande buvabilité. Longueur très appréciable de larrière-goût sans jamais tomber dans lamertume excessive ni dans le sucre résiduel écoeurant. Une bière absolument irréprochable dans son style que je pourrais facilement boire sur une base régulière.

650ml brown bottle. Lightly hazy and deep golden in the glass. White foam on top that settles into a thin consistent layer and eaves a lot of patchy lacework in the glass. The aroma has bitter citrus, tropical fruit, and resins, much hoppier and brighter than I was expecting for this style. Tastes very similar to the aroma, pine, orange peel, resin and tropical fruit. The malts seem a little hard to find for me, definitely a hop forward take to the style. Medium length aftertaste pine and oily orange peel. Really good.
Copper color and delicious. Resin with tropical notes. Very well balanced with a beautiful finish. Top notch.

Bottle into glass. An amazing aroma of citrusy hops that seems nicer on the nose than many other hoppy beers out there. Pours a clear reddish copper with white head. Taste is medium to heavy bitter. Full bodied with a creamy texture and bitter finish. An awesome hoppy bitter.

On tap at St. Augustines. Pours a clear pale copper with a tan head. Aroma is caramel, sweet, with tropical fruits notes. Taste is sweet, caramel, resin, tropical fruits bitterness. Sweet, tropical fruit bitterness aftertaste. Very good. Though not a ESB at all, but who cares? :-)
Elaborating later. Too citrusy to be an esb but who cares. Light pepper, almost oily, pine, caramel,
Poured from 650mL bottle. Clear orangey brown with off-white head. Tropical hops, caramel malt, light piney finish. Pretty decent overall.

Appearance: hazy pale amber with two fingers of loose off-white head diminishing fairly quickly to a thin skim, patchy lacing. (4/5) Aroma: tropical fruit, citrus, pine, caramel malt. (8/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate bitter. (8/10) Palate: medium body, moderate carbonation, lingering leafy hoppy black tea finish. (4/5)

Oh, Hildegard, you have been naughty, havent you, putting all those hops in the vicars bitter? Time for your spanking, you naughty nun, you! Lets find out what those stockings are attached to, anyway... (ahem) Where was I? Oh, yes, beer! Not nun-spanking. Not at all. On to the beer! And what a beer! No hesitation in saying this is the best ESB Ive ever had. I am loving this brewery - their witbier wasnt anything special, but when it comes time to bring the hops, they bring em in spades. Lots of complexity in the aroma, nicely balanced bitter and malt on the tongue, and a finish that honestly reminds me of nothing so much as unsweetened iced tea. Lovely. (16/20)

Really great esb. Pours a bright orange with a ruby red colour, thick off white head settles down to thin layer. Tons of sticky lacing. The aroma is fruity, tons of hoppy citrus and pine resin notes. Light caramel and biscuity malts, bit of toffee, bready. Very english style malt base. fruity citrus hops balance well. Tons of pinepple, light grapefruit, spicy hop notes, floral notes, light pine. Just easy going but also very complex and hoppy. Neat brew!

[5904-20131010] 650mL bottle. Fragrant fruity flower petal aroma. Clear, orange brown body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. Bitter herbal fruity flavour has a long leafy aftertaste. Medium body. Tasty, bitter. (7/3/7/3/14) 3.4
(w/ blankboy, Greg Clow, jercraigs, mds)

One of my favorite beer - This beer is amazing!
Unclear orange copper. Aroma of fresh pungent grassy herbal spicy hops. Taste is crisp and fresh moderate hoppy, herbal and spicy, some pine, with a sweet-ish malt base. 
This beer is outstanding - a must try for all craft beer drinkers.

From the bomber. Pours deep orange/amber. Medium head with some lacing. Smells of citrus, orange peel and pine resin. Smells more like an American IPA. Taste is malty upfront with a bitter finish. Like a Pale Ale with some bite. Good balance of sweetness and hop bitter. Bitter but refreshing. Nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber from CANBIF 2014. Dark amber with a beige head. Smells more like a fresh hopped IPA then an ESB but who knows...slightly musty hops, slightly wet, resin, bit of grapefruit. some caramel malt. Moderate carbonation and body, overall bitter but a fair amount of sweetness to balance things out until the end when the pine and grass along with citrus dominate. Tasty.

Bottle, thanks a lot David! Amber, rocky off-white head. Resinny pine and lychee hop aroma. Grapefruit, grass and pine hop notes on the palate, medium malt base, some saltiness. Bitter earthy finish. Certainly not lacking in flavour...

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2014 22oz bottle thanks to JonnyBeers @ BA, part of his CANBIF box to me. Pours a good and clear copper with a medium slightly off white head that leaves good lacing. Nose is light sulfur on the first whiff, caramel, fruits and earthy hops. Taste is moderately sweet and moderately bitter, a bit too sweet if you ask me but not a disaster at all. Flavors of caramel and fruity hops. Finish is strongly bitter and lingers for a long while. Body is medium, carbonation as well. Mouthfeel is quite oily and a little sticky at times. Overall a good beer, just a bit too heavy for me I think.

Bottle (650 ml). Thanks to Damon for this one! Slightly hazy copper with a medium off-white head and some lacing. Aroma is super hoppy (dank hops_ with nice mineral/earthy notes, resinous presence and caramel. Taste is mineral/earthy with caramel, resinous presence, good malt backbone, very light bitterness and light fruitiness. Light body. Moderate carbonation. Fluffy mouthfeel. Very nice mouthfeel. Theres a good amount of caramel and malt, but because of the mouthfeel its never cloying and its still super drinkable/quenching. A well executed hybrid between an English IPA and an ESB.

Bottle at Toms. Slight hazy copper pour with white head. Aroma is really hoppy, nice dank resinous hop, almost IPA like but with a good dose of earthy, caramel English malt. Taste is grassy, really hoppy, malty but very light palate which prevents it from getting too sticky or cloying, really tasty malt, rich caramel. Really nice.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2017 2017-04-24, bottle, 7-5-8-4-14=38Very grainy and herbaceous, overwhelming the resiny hops. Good, but a bit too much for me.2016-06-23, bottle from BCL, 8-5-8-4-16=41Compared to the tap I had a few days ago, the aroma is more expressive, more hoppy, clearly piney. Nice bready malts, I would be happier without the cereals touch, but its very clean, more than the tap, mild character from the yeast, and potent resiny hops, with a delicate fruity touch.Excellent.2016-06-18, draught at Alibi Room, Vancouver, 10oz, 7-5-7-3-14=36Amber color, clean. Some aroma of quality hop and caramel. Highly carbonated, a bit too sour, some malt and caramel, some British yeast, and resiny hopping, almost woody or vegetable.Robust beer, not as good as I remember from previous years.2014-09-04, bottle from Brewery Creek, Vancouver, 8-5-8-4-16=41Hazy bright amber color with medium head. Wonderful fresh Mosaic aroma, fruity, and some caramel. Light residual sweetness; the lean malt and caramel flavor is very good and doesnt hide the qualities of the hop; resiny and fruity final, but also a bit woody/vegetable; in the bottle it has just a bit more ESB flavor, otherwise its a pure IPA.2014-08-24, draught at Alibi Room, Vancouver, 8-5-8-5-17=43Amber color, clean, with compact head. Strong hop aroma, very fruity, with pineapple, mango and more. Sweetish caramel flavor, malt, then powerful hopping with plenty of resins and fruits, sweet oranges and some tropical fruits. Bold but balanced, clean and flawless.On draught? Delicious.

The Premium Bitter/ESB title isnt close to accurate, anyway... Bottle. Pours amber with a white head. Sweet, sugary, funky aroma with over ripe fruit... Medium body, medium carbonation. Theres candy, pine, lemon, orange, grapefruit, tangerine. Nice and juicy with a solid, slightly woody bitter finish. Tasty, but not what it says on the tin.

Smells fruity, almost topical, and malty. Pours clear brown with a light tan coloured head. 

Tastes malty, lightly burnt, nutty, a little spicy. The body is medium, carbonation is in the low side, the finish is bitter. 

A decent beer, if you looking for something bitter, strong by not too west coast. Nice to see the driftwood can make a great tasting IPA and an ESB.
Hoppy & sweet. Great mouthfeel. Smells like something and tastes like something else etc. Very good beer.

smells of pungent thick hopps fuckin killer smell pours dark amber with an off white sexy fresh smelling head the taste is undeniably just like an ipa but with a little something extra amazing beer try it if you can must try

Bottle [650ml] shared with GregClow, mds, jerc & mabel -- c/o j&m. Pours a murky orange-amber with a small semi-lasting frothy off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, sweet fruit and a good amount of earthy hops. Flavour of caramel malt, fruit and earthy hops. Moderate bitter finish. Average to medium bodied. Not sure if its on style but regardless, its pretty good.

Bomber. Unclear orange copper, firm foamy off-white head slowly fades. Aroma of fresh pungent grassy herbal spicy hops, some evergreen. Taste is crisp and fresh moderate hoppy, herbal and spicy, some pine, with a sweet-ish malt base. Soft carbonation, lighter bodied. ESB overlapping into PNW IPA territory. Deliciously drinkable makes it deserve a new designation: MLF (More Lagerboy Friendly) meaning more friendly than not.

2013-10-10. Dark orange amber body small but nice foamy beige head. 3+ Aroma is mild but pleasant. muted malt and light hoppy overtones. Flavour is also mild, sweetish base malt with notes of caramel. Average plus to medium bodied palate, soft carbonation. Bottle via trade with Ferris.
An ESB where the hops steal the show. A nice change. Driftwood is consistently putting out quality brews and putting Canada on the craft beer map.

Clear copper body with a massive white crown, lacing is redickulas, and the cap will not dissipate. Aroma is wacky wack wack. Big hops, massive every thing, all citrus, leathery. Is this really an ESB it seems very IPAish to me. Massive citrus flavour, big bitter, leather, earth, flowers. The bitterness lingers forever, but it also has a big sweetness. Awsome beer but is this an ESB.

Bottle: Poured a deep amber color ale with a relatively large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of earthy bitter hops with light dry caramel malt notes. Taste is also a well-balanced mxi between some earthy hops with some citrus bitter notes with a solid dry caramel malt backbone. Body is above average for style with good carbonation. Very enjoyable beer with nice earthy hops mix but not sure it has much to do with actual Bitter anymore.

Couleur de cuivre avec un col moyenne blanc et épais. Un arôme épicée et aussi dagrumes et houblon. Le goût et agrumes, miel, un peu dépices doux, avec une finale légèrement amer. Très facile à boire.

650 ml. (6.5%) pours a beautiful copper/ brown with a sudsy and frothy 2 finger head. Aroma is full of citrus and hops. Taste is floral, citrus, hops, honey, with some evident spices. Palate is smooth with flashes of citrus and hops. Exceptional caramel malt backbone and a warm mouthfeel. Very nice brew.
Wonderful ESB. Beautiful copper colour with small tannish head. Medium bodied, citrusy hops and really nice spicy, peppery finish. Great balance throughout this beer, very well done Driftwood.

hahaha compiling my beers i had in various closets, this one pops up. thought i had reviewed it, as i was giving a bunch of them away. its a bit passed its prime, but seems to be relatively fine. nice burnt orange colour, with citric bitter, and caramel aroma. Prominent orange flavour, spices, a bit of vanilla. good bitterness to it normally, but yeah, its a bit weak at this point, compared to when its fresh. typically has a lasting bitter finish to it.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2014 From a large bottle. Lots of tan head, but it falls quickly. Its a very promising amber color. Over the gums! Its a bitter, resiny, citrus hop-bomb, folks. Yes, theres some malt there in the background. An ESB thats actually bitter. Very refreshing!
And Aug 28, 2014 on tap at The Tangent in Vancouver. Still a great ESB in the newer actually bitter style.

Single bottle purchased from a BC Liqour Store on 08/11/2012 in Invermere, BC. Colour: Light red and dark brown mix with low head. Nose: Delicious dark bread, hints of mild cocoa, caramel, herbal hops, and a bit of glue. Taste: Medium sweet, medium bitter, medium-light sour. Some decent caramel sweetness accompanies a spiced herbal bitterness that runs through the palate. I love a beer that has a peppery spice and this one is just that. It comes strong accompanied by smooth hops in the finish. Long lingering.

Beautiful, complex aroma of pine and hops...however the taste had a great balance of malt and hops with a lean towards a quiet bite in the lingering finish. Full bodied with a creamy texture. Very impressed with this brew not to mention the label is awesome!

650 ml bottle. 2012 vintage. Pours an orange amber with a light head. Sour malty aroma with hops and caramel, almost like a barley wine. Flavors of fresh dark fruit, orange peel, toasted malts, and little bit of brown sugar. Nice carbonation. Light bitter finish. Much better than the 2011.

Bottle courtesy of James at a tasting at Andys the day after doing a tasting at Pauls.  Pours a clear caramel color with a thin to medium head.  Nice nutty malt, a touch of toast. Medium bodied, crisp malt and toast.  Nutty and toasty, good amount of malt.  Nice earthy bitterness.

Bottle shared at Andys. Pours a deep amber body with white lacing. Aroma is fresh bitter hop, light resin, light floral tones. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of spicy hops, light grass, and nice bitterness.

Bottle. Pours clear, light copper. Hoppy nose, orange, pine, some caramel. Lightly toasted malts with fruity and earthy hops. A bit thin mouthfeel, abrupt finish. A decent beer that I would not call a bitter/ESB

Haha I had lots of local ales in England and Scotland before joining this site but since I retried the Fullers ESB recently and loved it I thought I should from now on consider that the standard-bearer. I then go to the BJCP guidelines and it says "Judges should not judge all beers in this style as if they were Fullers ESB clones." so never mind. This is certainly the hoppiest example of its style Ive had yet; if it were made by an English brewer I think it would be labelled an IPA. However when I plug my nose and take a sip the sweet seems stronger than the bitter. The latest three Driftwood beers Ive had -- the saison, the altbier, and this -- are much more similar than youd expect. Not getting much of a biscuity flavour here, the only thing setting it apart are the English hops (which Im loving) which are painted across the typical well-crafted Driftwood canvas. For a moment I thought the finish was hot but thats pine (EDIT: No theres definitely warming alcohol here). Mild diacetyl. Good brew.
Aromas of leafy hops, toffee - very pleasant. Medium /full bodied. Medium bitterness, nicely balanced. Finish lingering bitterness and Im picking up a touch of sourness. Delicious.

Pours ruddy brown with thick foamy beige head. Heavy citrus hop aroma.Very strong orange over top of a deeper umami taste I couldnt quite identify -- roasted meat?  Full-bodied with a long finish. A very original offering.

650ml  bottle pours a light brown color with a finger and a half of white head and some really nice lacing.  Aroma is lightly toasted malts and floral hops.  Taste is balanced between floral and earthy hops with a light sweetness underneath.  A very fine representation of a bitter.  Well done.

Thanks to manuchampions for this.  Pours a deep amber with a nice frothy head and great lacing.  Aroma is a malty hop backbone with a hint of apple.  Taste is a great slow boil of hop bitterness with maltiness that is somewhat sweet and slight caramel.  Just a pleasure of a beer.
Fresh bottle from rutager.  Pours tan brown body with small retained white head.  Smells odd.  Taste is mild hoppy competing with some sourness and buttery.  Really not meeting the style.

Bottle, brought back and shared by Parksy. Dark orange amber, lacy orange tinted head. Initial aroma is orange rind and pine, then after a bit of time to breathe, some caramel, and a pungent earthiness emerge. Flavour has a nice toasty malt base with equal elements of fruity and earthy hops. A bit of a hash oil thing in here, which I love. Finish is juicy and bitter. Carbonation is medium, perfect for the lighter body this beer possesses. An absolutely awesome ESB!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
In short: An American style hop bomb IPA with an English twist.  Excellent session beer.
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed very fresh a few days after receiving it from presario. Thanks a lot Trevor.
The look: Slightly cloudy dark golden body topped by a medium off-white head with medium retention
In long: Nose is very aromatic with a ton of juicy leafy hops, pine tree notes.  Taste has a fair amount of toasted sweet cereals, half honey, half caramel.  A few dried fruits.  A lot of fruity hops, grassy hops, leafy hops, piney hops.  Finish is medium bitter, medium dry.  Carbonation is a lot of very small bubbles.  For anybody who was ever served a real ESB in England this is not much of an ESB.  More like an American IPA with an enlgish hops twist.  Whatever it is I thought it was excellent, tasty and very sessionnable.  One of the very best Canadian west-cost beer Ive had.  Wow, I rarely praise western Canadian beer but this is awesome.  Great sessions beers, one of the leading cause of the I love you man phrases being spoken in modern society.
Hazy amber,lasting tan head.Complex earthy carmel citrus hop nose.Faint carmel start medium citrus hop profile.Too citrusy for style

Poured a hazy dark orange body beneath a large ivory, rocky head.  Aroma was quite hoppy with malt undertones.  Flavour couldve been mistaken for an IPA, for again there was a generous hop presence underpinned with caramel.  Mouth began on the thin side, but as things progressed, it became more robust.  Nice embossed bottle, too.

Bottle purchased at Darbys on 16th and MacDonald in Vancouver. Beautiful, complex aroma of pine and hops...however the taste had a great balance of malt and hops with a lean towards a quiet bite in the lingering finish. Full bodied with a creamy texture. Very impressed with this brew and looking forward to trying more of Driftwoods beers.

Bottle. Deep caramel amber with thick off-white 1 finger head. Initial strong citric hop aroma with yeast. Carbonation is soft and abundant. Strong malt flavour, with a roast caramel taste. Well hopped, almost like a Northwest IPA. Lovely creation from Driftwoood.

Woody, earthy and floral spiciness to the hops in the nose with a pleasantly sweet caramel malt base.  Mild citrus character also emerges as it warms.  Hazy darkened copper coloured body is topped by a generous off white head that recedes to a lasting cover with very nice lacing.  Caramel malts are sweet up front and are then joined by a fairly pronounced bitterness with toasted malts coming out in the aftertaste.  Plenty of floral and earthy notes and some honey character round things out.  Medium body with moderate to strong carbonation that is pleasantly prickly on the tongue.  Really enjoyed this one a lot!  Tulip glass.  Cellar temperature.  Bottle purchased at Brewery Creek in Mar-10.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2011 Just had a bottle of the 2011 release. Marked improvement. The malt is so fresh and wonderfully aromatic. Theres a great puckering bitterness to the beer and yet its not overly hoppy. Solid rejigging of a decent beer making it superb.
**************
Bomber from 16th St. Liquor in West Vancouver. Pours a dark copper colour with a decent head. Taste is pleasantly malty but with that typically piney hop flavour that seems to be the brewerys hallmark. However the aroma is more rewarding than the taste. Ive had better ESBs but for a local one this is not bad.

(650ml bottle) Purchased at Spinnakers Wine and Spirits. Dissipated white head atop a copper body. Nose is very crisp with hops. Flavour is far more pronounced and hoppy than anticipated. Not an ordinary ESB. Great hop base with a happy yeastiness. Another good recipe from the local boys. Cheers!
Flowery woody nose. Reddy colour with a light head. Nice malt forward balance. Dry hoppy taste.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2016 On tap at the Alibi Room, pours a hazy orange with a small white head. Nose brings out lots of oranges, resinous hops and British caramel malt. Flavour is along the same lines, with loads of resinous hops, caramel malt, British bready malt and oranges. Not an authentic ESB, but more like an IPA. Resinous and orangey on the finish, with ample sweetness. Very nice.
pours a nice dark copper colour with a nice little bubble head which leaves a light lacing on the glass. nice smooth bitter flavour with a great aroma.

Bottle shared by CapFlu. Is dark amber and hazy with nice tight cream-colored head. Bright cannabis hop aroma. Soft palate. Delicious, big hoppy flavors with nice biscuity and nutty malts carrying the base. Nice and balanced.

Golden-amber.  Bright woodsy hop aroma with earthy, caramelly malt.  Bright, woody, earthy palate with a hint of citrus.  Complex, nice yeastiness.  Has new world character with an old world sense of balance.  Interesting.
